session_1747385070975_skiyxqw: To what extent do you support or oppose the widespread deployment of surveillance cameras in public spaces? Please explain your reasoning.
column3: do not support it. Reason being, I don't trust the police to begin with. I think that surveillance is an invasion of privacy, and while yes, it might increase safety because people are worried about being recorded, it's not a foolproof means, and if you watch any true crime documentaries or anything of the sort, then it definitely does not deter people, and people can easily disguise their faces, and people can easily disappear or figure out where it is, and of course police can abuse that, knowing where they are, if police are the ones in charge. Either way, it's an invasion of privacy, and I would be very uncomfortable being surveyed everywhere I walk or go or drive.

session_1747385070975_skiyxqw: What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing surveillance camera coverage in urban areas?
column3: I think the most positive impact is probably just extra safety. Maybe it'll make people feel a bit safer, it might deter people from committing some very obvious crimes. I think that negative is it is an invasion of privacy, it can be used against people, it can be used for blackmail, it can be used in nefarious ways, and it's really difficult to trust the people in charge. I wouldn't personally.

session_1747385070975_skiyxqw: How do you think surveillance technologies might affect public safety and crime rates?
column3: I think that it would definitely make things a little bit safer. It might deter crime just a bit. In lots of cities that do have very good surveillance, crime is still pretty up there. I don't think it would really deter anybody. I mean, people already know that DNA evidence, like, most crimes will get figured out for the most part. I would say it would decrease maybe petty crimes like car break-ins in areas where there's surveillance. But even then, people can just wear hoods. There will still be really dumb people. I think that crime rates would go down, but it wouldn't be significant enough to be worth the breach of privacy.

session_1747385070975_skiyxqw: What impact do you believe increased surveillance might have on personal privacy and individual liberties?
column3: it would have a significant effect. As I've mentioned before, personal privacy would be jeopardized. It would be very difficult to believe that you are not being watched. If you have a stalker, for instance, in the police force, if they're the ones regulating it, that would be absolutely terrible. I think it would make me feel more unsafe and it would make me feel safe, honestly, especially in my own neighborhood where I feel relatively safe a lot of the time. I think that it can definitely be used for things like blackmail. It can be used against people and it would definitely take away liberty, but I don't know how to explain that as well as I do just a breach of privacy.

session_1747385070975_skiyxqw: How do you think surveillance camera systems might affect community trust and police-community relations?
column3: I think it would have community trust, I think, would not be affected. I think that within communities in some areas, it's already a good amount of trust. If anything, I think the idea of needing surveillance cameras might make people a little bit more weary of others, just considering it's there. Like, yeah, you might feel personally safer, but it's already like, wow, I really can't trust the people around me, huh? That's why we have these cameras, that kind of energy. As for police community relations, they're already pretty terrible for the most part. I'm generalizing there, but from my experience, they're absolutely terrible to begin with. It's a corrupt organization, in my opinion, already. So adding more power to that would be absolutely devastating to police community relations.

session_1747385070975_skiyxqw: What role do you believe government should play in regulating surveillance technologies and data collection?
column3: Absolutely none. It's similar to police. I don't think that people in power should have this sort of data on civilians. It is a huge breach of privacy and it does not make me feel safe. I would not want that. I think it would be absolutely terrible. I think that if this is going to be a thing, if there is going to be some sort of surveillance, it absolutely should be community elected individuals. It should be people who are seen generally as trustworthy, who can prove they are trustworthy, who are seen by the general public as trustworthy. Not just the government. I think that that's absolutely terrible. It should be a local thing. It should not be a nationwide thing. And of course, people think organizations like the FBI are absolutely going to have access to it. It just feels like this can easily be used to turn things into a fascist state if we don't disallow the government from being involved in that.

session_1747385070975_skiyxqw: How might technological concerns about accuracy and reliability factor into decisions about surveillance systems?
column3: I mean, it absolutely factors in. For instance, it could be like, oh, well, we saw the person who committed this crime was a big black man, for instance. And of course, the wrong person might be absolutely convicted. Or for instance, they might see somebody, it might look dark. And of course, with stereotypes and with the way that this racist judicial system works, they'll be like, oh, oh, it might totally just be some white dude who looks dark in the image, you know? Or like some white dude who looks tanned. They'll be like, oh, it was a Latino or oh, it was a black man, you know? Something like that. And absolutely, it'll be used to profile. There's no way, it's going to be really bad. The grainy footage, it's not like we're gonna have HD cameras on every street. It's going to be grainy, especially at night. And I wouldn't even say they're that reliable. Yeah, it might be helpful, but there's no way it would be used for profiling. There's no way it wouldn't be used for profiling, I mean.
